New books: a bunch of memoirs from various authors cuz i just dig those,  Edgar Sawtelle, Lincoln's Team of Rivals, Hurry Down Sunshine, want to buy a bunch more available on amazon cuz they're only.1 cent plus shipping, which equals something way cheaper than barnes and noble. I never can find anything in person anyway. I was made for the world wide web.

marshall's spending spree...amazon.com spending spree....hello tax refund. 

I want a Kindle so badly but feel like its just a hook, to you know, spend more. Once you purchase it then you browse through the books and purchase those. Most of them are 9.99, but with me it wouldn't matter because a thousand masterpieces would be quite literally at my fingertips--I'd end up buying hundreds of books in one ten minute sitting. No, I'm sorry. I wouldn't be sitting, I'd be lying down on my bed. That seems wrong. My poor bank account which already suffers. 


Have been reading the Unabridged Journals of Sylvia Plath. God damn people who romanticise suicide. Was I one of those people? I hope not, because trying to rent that heavy lovely albatross from the library is to get many concerned stares back from the people behind the desk. What? I;m sorry that Emily Dickinson's journal entries weren't available, and frankly her vernacular is at times a bit out of my reach. Sylvia is just right. There are no great writers who would ever allow their journals to be put on display, except Sylvia. Maybe even she wouldnt have allowed it. But its as good as reading a book of her poetry, her feelings and observations are just as crisp, and  her "casual" writing style puts mine to shame. Really, no one writes a diary entry like that anymore. Just typing this out right now  makes me ashamed at how dumbed down my inner monologue is, when its transcribed onto the page. All of my generation, really. We dont use punctuation, we dont know what adverbs articles predicates are. The adjectives we use are chosen from one of three, and no one really cares. 

On that note, I'm gonna goes and reads some more o' that aweeesome hyperbole of hers.

What is it with celebrities and fashion lines? Why? Do they want a huge closet where they don't have to pay money to wear cool shit? Do they just wanna make money? I have a hard time swallowing the whole "creative urge with talent" bit when it comes to celeb clothing lines simply because it takes years for designers to perfect their craft. Its art. (Sort of like when James Franco had a gallery showing for his paintings, mmm although visual art is more subjective than a pair of pants though. You know a pair of pants are crap when you put them on and the crotch is where the knee is supposed to be. Modern art is more illusive, never really sure if its original or crap) But then again these celebs dont have a hand in the actually crafting of their clothes, they dont even know how to sew! Actual fashion designers spent years in costume design or in classrooms, in front of the sewing machine, behind the desk at the cleaners learning bespoke. I bet Vera Wang and Stella McCartney are slighting puking in their leather booties considering they have to compete with crap like J.Lo's jogging suits or Justin's William Rast. I mean, thats what you get I suppose when you try to make good fashion affordable at H&M or Kohls. 

I dont know why I suddenly decided to write about that. Justin was on Oprah today and I think hes really funny, not a huge fan of his music but a fan of the Elton John duet he did, and he seems like a good entertaining talented musician. Then why the clothing line? Everybody wants to be a mogul I guess.

Ugh.
Thats what Cleo says as she walks out of the Astrologists office, glaring into her reflection, longingly.
 This movie, Cleo from 5 to 7 by Agnes Vardas, follows a french chanteuse in real time for two hours while she awaits the results of a biopsy. She runs around Paris like a baby doll, happy to be sad, staring into mirrors whenever confronted with the possibily of death or illness.  I hate to love and love to hate her, because in the end she gets what she wants. Her illness.
Maybe she doesnt want it, but I get the feeling she does. It is more melodrama. Something she is used to.
She starts out very weak with the above proclamation, but by the end, she emerges (or is supposed to emerge) stronger. Do I like her more? Eh. Not really. I didnt get that feeling at all. Maybe it was bad acting.
 Maybe I was just upset to see a woman equate beauty to health. That idea never left my head. It haunted me. Because though this film is shot like a documentary about one woman, but you get the feeling that she is echoing several generations of females who think the same way. Instead of letting that concept blossom, it just lays there. Enter seedy French man who likes to talk about nudity.
 Lets see...
    If you like staring at a model's face, then maybe you'll like this film. And sometimes I do like to do that. Sometimes I like to stare, sometimes my eyes are hypnotized by the contours of a woman's cheeks, her ski-slope nose, her chin made of glass. But mostly its when this kind of beauty is paired with confidence and tralala-ishness, that I become a real voyeur, like a child pauper staring into the window of a candy shop. I had those moments in this movie. Like, wow. and...jeez nice apartment.
 I hope Vardas' intention was to either have a complete joke on us, or ya know, make us think. For me, I wasnt so interested in the fact that Cleo becomes kinder and less selfish as the film progresses, b/c as I said she was still pretty annoying by the end of the movie. The only thing of value I took away from the shabang was how self-involvement can be a cancer, and sometimes it takes the real thing (or another kind of life-changing event) to snap a person out of it.

Prudes at Dinner, Gluttons in Bed

By George F. Will
 Thursday, February 26, 2009; Page A19

Put down that cheeseburger and listen up: If food has become what sex was a generation ago -- the intimidatingly intelligent Mary Eberstadt says it has -- then a cheeseburger is akin to adultery, or worse. As eating has become highly charged with moral judgments, sex has become notably less so, and Eberstadt, a fellow at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, thinks these trends involving two primal appetites are related.
In a Policy Review essay, "Is Food the New Sex?" -- it has a section titled "Broccoli, pornography, and Kant" -- she notes that for the first time ever, most people in advanced nations "are more or less free to have all the sex and food they want." One might think, she says, either that food and sex would both be pursued with an ardor heedless of consequences, or that both would be subjected to analogous codes constraining consumption. The opposite has happened -- mindful eating and mindless sex. Imagine, says Eberstadt, a 30-year-old Betty in 1958, and her 30-year-old granddaughter Jennifer today. Betty's kitchen is replete with things -- red meat, dairy products, refined sugars, etc. -- that nutritionists now instruct us to minimize. She serves meat from her freezer, accompanied by this and that from jars. If she serves anything "fresh," it would be a potato. If she thinks about food, she thinks only about what she enjoys, not what she, and everyone else, ought to eat.
Jennifer pays close attention to food, about which she has strong opinions. She eats neither red meat nor endangered fish, buys "organic" meat and produce, fresh fruits and vegetables, and has only ice in her freezer. These choices are, for her, matters of right and wrong. Regarding food, writes Eberstadt, Jennifer exemplifies Immanuel Kant's Categorical Imperative: She acts according to rules she thinks are universally valid and should be universally embraced.

Betty would be baffled by draping moral abstractions over food, a mere matter of personal taste. Regarding sex, however, she had her Categorical Imperative -- the 1950s' encompassing sexual ethic that proscribed almost all sex outside of marriage. Jennifer is a Whole Foods Woman, an apostle of thoroughly thought-out eating. She bristles with judgments -- moral as well as nutritional -- about eating, but she is essentially laissez-faire about sex.

In 50 years, Eberstadt writes, for many people "the moral poles of sex and food have been reversed." Today, there is, concerning food, "a level of metaphysical attentiveness" previously invested in sex; there are more "schismatic differences" about food than about (other) religions.

If food is the new sex, Eberstadt asks, "where does that leave sex?" She says it leaves much of sex dumbed-down -- junk sex akin to junk food. It also leaves sexual attitudes poised for a reversal. Since Betty's era, abundant research has demonstrated that diet can have potent effects, beneficial or injurious. Now, says Eberstadt, an empirical record is being assembled about the societal costs of laissez-faire sex.

Eberstadt says two generations of "social science replete with studies, surveys and regression analyses galore" have produced clear findings: "The sexual revolution -- meaning the widespread extension of sex outside of marriage and frequently outside commitment of any kind -- has had negative effects on many people, chiefly the most vulnerable; and it has also had clear financial costs to society at large."

In 1965, the Moynihan Report sounded an alarm about 23.6 percent of African American children born out of wedlock. Today the figure for the entire American population is 38.5 percent, and 70.7 percent for African Americans. To that, add AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases, and the unquantifiable coarsening of the culture and devaluing of personal intimacy.

Today "the all-you-can-eat buffet" is stigmatized and the "sexual smorgasbord" is not. Eberstadt's surmise about a society "puritanical about food, and licentious about sex" is this: "The rules being drawn around food receive some force from the fact that people are uncomfortable with how far the sexual revolution has gone -- and not knowing what to do about it, they turn for increasing consolation to mining morality out of what they eat."

Perhaps. Stigmas are compasses, pointing toward society's sense of its prerequisites for self-protection. Furthermore, as increasing numbers of people are led to a materialist understanding of life -- who say not that "I have a body" but that "I am a body" -- society becomes more obsessive about the body's maintenance. Alas, expiration is written into the leases we have on our bodies, so bon appetit.

I no longer sleep at night for some reason but reserve the time period after dinner until midnight for that, or at least my body does, involuntarily. Sooooooooo, while I was up at 3am I decided to watch some pirated videos on the web. Or just one. Two Lovers. Except I had to watch the second part first and the first part second because well, thats how it works when you watch something illegally.  Ironically the movie was sooo incredible and I think it had to do with the order in which I watched it.
But it also had to do with director James Grey, who captures NYC so well. Sort of like the anti-Woody Allen. While Allen captures its quirks, Grey captures the melodrama, the accent, the cultural mix, the Brighton Beachiness of it all (whatever its a word to me...)
Joaquin was fantastic, his character is so genuine and sincere, but hes also so flipping sexy. You know there are just no dashing "open wounds" walking around NYC like him, but you hold back that slight misgrievance because a)he's compelling b) he's sexy. Did I mention that already, yes i did.
Gwyneth was actually great too, possibly the best she's been since oh i donno, Shakespeare in Love. We all love to hate her and her Goop, she is kind of goopy.
And Isabella Rosselini as the mom...love her.

So check check check. Good good good. Oh, and if you have the opportunity, start it at the middle and watch it like that :)

I'm a sucker for big show-stoppers, so I personally loved the Oscars tonight. I thought it would be humdrum, but i'm, like i said, kind of a Broadway freak (though the no money thing has stopped my habit temporarily)  so I fell right in line once Hugh started swinging his sexually ambiguous hips.  I can understand why some dont watch it, why some didnt like it, felt it was cheesy, but in this case I'm all about the cheese. That plus Sean Penn's speech was worth it.  In the end, I love movies. All kinds. If only I wasnt so agoraphobic I'd have actually seen more of them! Tis all.

I'm reading the tell-all biography by Quentin Bell on Virginia Woolf. Its an old book but I found it in my mother's collection so have been reading passages on and off for the past year.  I'm so fascinated by the Bloomsbury Movement, if I could I'd form my own. But we're all so perhaps overly connected sometimes w/ internet etc. Wouldnt it be rad though? THe women within the group were quite avant-garde for the times, one of them, Lady Otteline Morrell died her hair a soft purple, Vanessa Stephen, Virginia's sister wore extravagant robes...oh yeah and they of course discussed literature politics art and the like. Yes, like an artist colony. An acquaintance of mine went to a colony in the South of France, sculptors, painters, writers and the like. It seemed marvelous. I imagine being around all of that creative energy has to feed you in ways sitting inside a boring suburban house on Beacon Hill cant. I also have no discipline. When I took a class last year I miraculously spat out all of this stuff I didnt even know I was capable of anymore. But without any direction I'm sort of uninspired. Maybe an artist colony wouldnt be so good for me then. But it'd be an awesome thing to try, if just for the experience, and the friends one could potentially make. Apparently you have to submit your pieces and then they accept you based on the potential. And I love the South of France, its the only place in France I found mildy enchanting! Paris sucked, the French will even tell you that. Anyway, ruminations abound. If not an artist colony, or a decent piece of art, then maybe travel...somewhere....and soooon.

The film Heartburn is amazing. I watched it and it totally made a mediocre day so much better. Just had to express that. And, ya know, gotta love women like Nora Ephron who get back at their asshole ex-spouses by writing a hit-making novel-turned-screenplay that is still celebrated today.

I love that name. I told my mother and she said, "PITS?! PITSeleh?!"  It means "little one" in hebrew.  The song is beautiful. As are all of Elliot's pieces. WHenever I hear his voice, whether its part of a soundtrack from a movie playing on tv one day, or if I come across it on someone's myspace or whatnot, it brings me back to adolescence. Thats who I listened to growing up, a means of protection, it was, against the cruel realties of junior high and high school. I defintely developed a wall between me and other people, and my reality were always the dreams I had in my head. 
 As the year closes in on all of us, I think of what an appropriate resolution should be. And for me. I think its to just be better, well, to face reality with more hope, not look back and say, "what could have been?". Learning to fall forward, as they say. I also hope to someday find good people, not fake, or unhealthy people, but real good kind-hearted people, which means I too have to learn to reach out and be kind and well-wishing. My blood BOILS, CURDLES, sometimes at the thought of friends or people who I've felt betrayed by. Ick. I'm sure it goes without saying I've been that "mean" person to someone else. SOrt of like the plot line towards the end of ROmy and Michelle's High School Renunion where Jeaneane Garaffalo's character is ecstatic to realize that even in her teenage misery (caused by the reigning alpha females) she actually made someone else miserable too...

"I HURT YOUR FEELINGS, TOBY? TREMENDOUS! THATS TREMENDOUS! Go get your stupid yearbook, I would be happy to sign it!"

Hah.

You know I wasnt super close to the guy. And I always treated him like he was a dangerous animal who, if i stepped too close, might bite my hand off (like i treat most womanizing boarding school twats), but his sister just killed herself. July 25th...the morning of. I cant believe it. We ran in the same circle of friends during sophomore year of college. Its so sad and screwed up. But whats even more screwed up is that I found all of this out through....facebook? Yeah. Facebook. I noticed that a friend in NY had been invited to join a group called "Celebrating Olivia." And I feel like a complete amoeba on a flea on a rat for saying so, or perhaps Larry David's spiritual twin, but the first emotion i experienced before sadness and complete shock was this terrible thing called Facebook envy that makes me, of course after I send Julian a message expressing my condolences, want to drop that ridiculous website all together: Yes, thats right, why wasnt I invited to join this group like all the other fake friends he has who were invited to join?! Maybe its like Josh said, a natural instinct we feel when we're being neglected from certain important events that go on amongst our social circles. (He phrased it better at the time) Gosh, I dont believe in hell, but there are moments where I certainly feel I belong there. Rest aside, I'm just feeling kind of sick, really, that she felt there was no way out, didnt have anybody to talk to or go to for help, feeling trapped and somethng so beyond sadness. I dont know the exact circumstances. 

I took a personal day off today. Feeling kind of down and confused about the direction of my life. Told them I was having "stomach" issues. I called my mom and she read me a story I wrote when I was twelve about a girl who isnt allowed to take her most treasured possession, her blanket with her, (blankie) and the blanket embarks on a journey to find her. Even though I, at times, am upset that my mother cant relate or help me on days when i need it the most , well today was not one of those days. 
She reminded me of what I was good at, and who I was and still am, and that feeling crappy and sad (about dumping sensors into sensor bins) is a natural emotion that most people with creative temperments will experience, until they finally admit they have to find a path, carve a path, that is right for them. Even if it takes months to years and a lot of chutzpah to find the job, right graduate program, ashram in India, whatever. 
And I'm sad that Olivia didnt have that  same kind of phone call or emotional anchor. She should have. She should have.





Rest in peace, Olivia. 


Depressing post. Ok, thats it. Goodnight.

Some  days I go to work and its ok. Some days I hide inside the back office when I'm really supposed to be out on the sales floor ensuring proper custumer service. I'm honestly a shy person, friendly. sort of, but groups of people, strangers-- they kind of scare me. Sometimes eye contact is so terrifying my eyes flicker and I have to squint! How did I end up being a mananger at a retail store again? Toto we're not in Kansas anymore. 

Everything I generally write about on Livejournal usually revolves around the superficial aspects of my life, because its more fun that way. I dont want to write about all the icky personal stuff, but at the same time I feel like I'm lying to myself if I dont. Why cant people just abandon their awful judgements and love one anotha?!

One of my favorite poets is Louise Gluck, (pronounced Glick). Alot of critics despise her because they see her as being overly seratonin-level obsessed, doesnt utilize the negative capability, and all about depression and sadness and well, herself. Helloooo, thats what confessional poetry is!  Anyway, theres one poem of hers that I really love. It hits at the heart of how I feel about my life, path, self, and also what I know others are going through/have been through. Life is tough. I spent a year in bed deciding whether or not I wanted to continue mine. There's nothing more embarassing to me than having to explain to people what I did during that period of time I was absent from school, didnt pick up my friend's phone calls, terrified my parents, couldnt even muster up the courage to walk into a 7-11. (which is why i say I took an art class and worked at home) But that period is such a part of who I am, and the recovery part of it is, too. Theres no easy way out. One must go through. And there is something so beautiful and cathartic about hitting rockbottom and then coming out on the other side with a different perspective on life. I guess what I mean to say is, when all of those stupid overly cheery people I work with come to me with their judgements, I now know to look at them. And yawn. 

This is the poem. 


The Wild Iris


At the end of my suffering
there was a door.

Hear me out: that which you call death
I remember.

Overhead, noises, branches of the pine shifting.
Then nothing. The weak sun
flickered over the dry surface.

It is terrible to survive
as consciousness
buried in the dark earth.

Then it was over: that which you fear, being
a soul and unable
to speak, ending abruptly, the stiff earth
bending a little. And what I took to be
birds darting in low shrubs.

You who do not remember
passage from the other world
I tell you I could speak again: whatever
returns from oblivion returns
to find a voice:

from the center of my life came
a great fountain, deep blue
shadows on azure sea water.

Live journal is all about friendly debate. But it seems the only ones who want to talk about politics within my LJ circle are my brother or Ryan. Props to you.  I wish I could find a Hillary supporter out there with more political wisdom and objectivity than I, then I could partake in truly invigorating debate. Dont you think? But where are all the intellectual  Hillary Supporters that dont leave a bitter aftertaste after they're done expressing their views? I suspect there are very few of those kinds of people. I have to say, if you come across a bitter Hillary supporter its probably because she's a woman who has grown up fighting the glass ceiling, hates wheatgrass but does the diet anyway to measure up to standards, and is still getting over her adoloscent Ophelia complex. Yes, alot of female Hillary supporters are bitter about the way the election is turning out, and its not because they dont want Obama to win, its because they dont want Hillary to lose. Sometimes I think its men who have the greater luxury of being objective and empassioned over a political candidate, because it's just a tad bit easier for you, boys, however much you complain about your life. And I'm happy that people are rallying together in support of a great guy who is a democrat (thank God) and who holds great promise for our country. For some reason, I want Hillary to win. And it has nothing to do with politics, nada. Its because she's a woman. Simple as that. WRONG as that. I want to see a woman like me as president of the United States. And if/when she loses its going to hurt me, personally hurt me, like we're still not good enough. Another fucking example of how women are just not there yet. And all of the Obama supporters, black, white, hispanic, whatever, will cry tears of joy at Obama's inauguration, particularly every African-American thats had to fight their way towards equality. Lets face it, this election isnt just about politics. Its become personal. 

 Its funny. Josh and I talk all the time about debating and how women tend to shy away from it when confronting a well-informed male. When it comes to someone like my brother, who is so well-informed, so intelligent, and just basically so naturally gifted in the realm of verbal artistry theres no way you can win a friendly argument with him!  Every time I post something slightly controversial it feels like the first time i decided to raise my hand in AP European history class because I knew all the smart boys were watching, listening, and waiting to completely massacre any idea or tidbit I wanted to put out there. And even if it held no weight, I just wanted to know they heard my voice. Hellooo, I'm here. I'm smart, too. I'm more than a face or a body or a pose. It took alot of courage for me to raise my hand, probably once a quarter term did I do it.   Sink or swim. Sink or swim, thats what it felt like. I can remember the feeling, still. But I give much credit to my mother, who always told me I was brilliant and could do anything I wanted to do, becaus she grew up being told the exact opposite.

 Regardless of how you feel about Hillary or who you voted for in the primaries, and who you're going to vote for in the general election, Hillary is a brave woman. And misogyny is still out there and kicking, and I believe it's the reason why she's going to lose this one.

Thats that. Now I'll go back to being coy and cute. Happy Valentine's Day, everybody. Love thyself. :)

"The Eskimos had 52 names for snow because it was important to them," wrote novelist Margaret Atwood. "There ought to be as many for love." Your assignment, should you choose to accept it, is to coin at least nine of those 52 new names between now and January 1, 2009. Of course that means you will have to discover or create nine alternate states of love that have previously been unnamed. And to do that, you'll have to put aside your habitual expectations and standard definitions of what constitutes love so that you can explore an amazing array of nuances, including varieties you never imagined existed. 

-freewill astrology 


Actually, when I was feeling down and out and kind of bored last summer I painted the words on canvas, dissapointed that in fact it wasnt the word love that existed in 300 versions, but snow. Of course it makes sense, they even have a word for a man who has snow stuck in his beard! I love it. And this horoscope. It couldn't be more right on, at least for me.

I got a  message telling me so.....Happy Birthday,
spamjavelin

So the pats lost. You know I didnt even know the superbowl was today until some of the males in my life reminded me. So, how does one go from not even knowing about an event to being bummed out about the way it eventually went down? It must be those silver helments, I do think the Patriots have the best uniform in the league. or conference. or whichever is correct.  And then there's the Brady. Who I'm sincerely not into, though there was a moment that caught my eye. More out of pure humour than anything else, but during some time out he actually walked past his teammates and stood in front of the camera on the field with his hands on his hips and looked out into the distance, and the camera-guy sooo panned around him as if to really emphasize how much he is, as Josh later hysterically called it,  the NFL's David.  Hahahaha. 

I havent written much lately on live journal, because there isnt much to say. Oh, I bleached my hair and had the stylist cut some mild bangs. So now I have mild "bangage." Hot. Ha. 

And jobs, well, I dont want to curse anything so I'll just say things are going slow but steady in the job search. tis all.

And, I really want to quit smoking, but I am so hankering for one so I think I'll have my fourth or so of the day before I go to sleep.
This seems to be a very random non-purposeful sort of directionless post. So be it. 

Later everyone

I cry conspiracy! conspiracy! WTF is going on? And in the words of billy joel, why is it that only the good die young? (and we're still left with Britney's annoying british accent.)

For instance, Ingrid Michaelson was on Conan last night, she sings that song, "The Way I Am"...its been taken by Sears or some TJ Maxx like store and now whenever i hear it all I can think about are sweaters or kitchenware. Grrr.

just saw No Country for Old Men. I dont know exactly what to say, I love the Coen brothers films. It was good. Go see it. Javier Bardem was utterly freaky. Good acting. Always love Tommy Lee Jones, and Woody Harrelson.

So....I'm done! 'm done? I'm done. Finally done with school. (at least as an undergrad)
I wish I had something clever to go along with this. I am so enjoying reading the last few days worth of Live Journals. I had to block myself from viewing any websites that didnt have to do with either Jesus, Old-Time Music Theory, or the prospect of democratiziation in Iraq for the past few days. (It  takes will-power to keep my un-treated ADD in check ha) So now I'm catching up, and boy what a feast for realz! (this is why i love LJ)

Josh and I drove back home to NY. I'm sitting in the living room right now in front of the walmart-purchased christmas tree (hehehe, yayy walmart and their bargains! at least its real and gives off that woodsy pine smell) while the little bichon goes to town on a bone. Its so weird to be home. I was grumpy this morning. Its that fear of suburbia thing. I've definitely developed it. It would take two hours in order to get to a real city from here, just interesting to know. But its ok. Good to see the fam. I'm gonna start re-doing my resume, and then job searching of course. There are some that will take applications online etc etc. For the next, hmmm, two days, I wont think about it. No, that wont happen. Theres literally nothing else to think about here. I guess thats not a bad thing.

"At Free Will Astrology, we love to turn things upside-down and inside-out every now and then. It keeps our mental hygiene sparkling clean, and yours, too. This week, in order to incite a purifying ruckus, we're offering you a challenge from psychologist James Hillman. Please suck the following thoughts into the deepest recesses of your understanding, and enjoy the brainstorms they detonate: "By accepting the idea that you are the effect of a subtle buffeting between hereditary and societal forces, you reduce yourself to a result. The more your life is accounted for by what already occurred in your chromosomes, by what your parents did or didn't do, and by your early years now long past, the more your biography is the story of a victim." What I'm trying to tell you, Virgo, is that it's a fine time to rebel against your genetic heritage, your upbringing, and your conditioning. Imagine a life for yourself in which you don't believe that those factors control what you're capable of. "



Imagine that.

I was told today that my friend Matt's girlfriend is in the hospital with kidney and liver failure, and the chances of her recovering without a liver transplant are slim. Doctors can be wrong sometimes, cant they? 
She's 22 years old. An Iraqi war Marine veteran, deployed twice, survived twice. I mean, I knew she had some problems to work out (as well all do) and was making some not so "healthy" choices with her life, the reason why her liver failed is not so clear at the moment. Well, it is and it isnt. 
Last time I saw her she cooked dinner for all of us: lemon pasta, chicken cutlets, and a tangerine-infused cake. It was delicious. They had just moved into an apartment together and were slowly getting furniture/decorating the place. I have no idea what to do. Matt hasnt called me. His mother (my mom's best friend) hasnt called me. I feel like I should do something but to be truthful I dont even know what hospital she is in. She was really only an aquaintance but I had hope to forge a friendship with her. I'm praying for her recovery.
i am sooo tired, but have soooo much to do. boo.
peace. sanity. calm. solitude: sweet absence of faces.

Ivan was telling me about this really cool poetry workshop that takes place in St. Petersburg while theres 10 day of constant sunshine? Sounded very interesting. His sister did it apparently, she's been published in a number of poetry journals apparently. (though when you google her she doesnt really come up. anywho, just interesting stuff. where would i find the revenue for that? dont know, but just something to keep in the back of my mind, with all of the other stuff.) 

goodnight.

So that dude I've been scoping out stopped by the apartment with a nice bottle of pinot grigio the other night. (my favorite kind of wine) Now that I think about it, he showed it to me with a look of pride as if he already knew it was my favorite. (is he spying?) Nah, it was nice, we chatted for two hours or so. Hes a very learned figure. His thesis paper is basically proposing a strategy to set up some sort of safety net/security program/health plan for people living along the Chechnyan/Georgian border. As we all know, things there= not so good. Rabies is actually one of their biggest problems due to the rabid dogs. Yikes.  As he told me his stories, I felt the urge to drink more. As I started to lull into a sort of Victor Hugo-esque state of mind (he always encouraged people to "drink while the cup is full!") I realized how much we had in common and how little we had in common. Doesnt really matter. I guess I just didnt feel the same chemistry I did when I first sought him out. I was REALLY nervous. Cant help it. (virgos rule the nervous system) Plus, yes, thats right: he has a girlfriend. Though he places his relationship in the "wreckage" status, I told him its all good and we've got a friendship going. La de da.
There was something sort of creepy about him though, I cant put my finger on it exactly. Its like, he doesnt blink or something. Haven't quite figured it out yet. I did his birth chart. His moon mercury and venus are all in virgo, which makes alot of sense why we initially connected.

I dont know just keeping my options open really. Its always nice to get to know someone better, and you never know with me.   My desires change every day. (although if asshole called me at 4am in the morning again I'd probably make the same trip over in my pajamas just to see him) AHHH! 

_____ Warning: Josh, you may find reading this stuff below uncomfortable from older brother perspective. Just a heads up. I really didnt feel like re-customizing my journals, I'm getting tired but wanted to get all these things off me' chest. ___


As far as sexuality goes (yes I'm going there, please fear not, just the ramblings of a quizzical Gemini-Rising) I'm attracted to the human being first and foremost, the physicality comes second.  This fact has had a strange effect upon the various people I've expressed it to, depending upon how I preface it. Par exemple: one of my best gal friends took it as a hint that she could hit on me once she decided she wanted to try dating women. AKA: that WASNT pleasant. (I still have a hard time telling people I"M NOT INTERESTED for fear of hurting them. That gets me into sticky situations) Anyway, other people may think I'm some sort of Sinead O'Connor wannabe, saying things like "I'm 75 percent straight and 25 percent bisexual." I'm just trying to get to the heart of the matter, who I am, To be honest, I'd prefer a man, but I do feel for women, sometimes feel bad for them. (for me? NEVA) I was raised to be suspiscious and untrusting of the opposite sex, which I feel was a mistake on my parents part, but all is forgiven. All in all, the path to full sexual/ spiritual liberation for me has been and is a very interesting one. I'm only at the beginning. 

Forget the Ambien just read my livejournals! Sweet dreams Earthlings.

I'm so tense I could, well, I could, I could squeeze something. Very hard. And it would break. If it were a breakable sort of thing.

I have a test tomorrow that I am so unprepared for. The only respite I have besides the tutor this mornin (who helped me thank Garsh) is the Arrested Development DVD pack of Season 1 Sara lent to me. (Thank you!) Everytime I watch it between breaks I just think, "hey, in the end, if things dont work out the way I planned, I could always just buy a scooter, learn some shoddy magic tricks, and drive my family nuts for the rest of my life." Not that that'll happen. But watching that show makes me feel so good. I just think of Tobias's cutoff and I am immeditately zen with the world. I mean, Come on! ('nother reference)

And then there are the parralels I could draw between their ridiculous antics and my own family's ridiculous antics. But I shant go there. Dysfunction has its place. And so does TV. In small doses they really make me feel like everything
is gonna be 

ooookkkkkkkkkk.

 ::drifts off on a raft somewhere in the cerulean blue oceans of Bermudaaaaa::

sweet sweet boloudos. Utopia is NOT utopia. Yes, a courageous man, when forced into a terrible situation, would steal rather than cringe. But Thomas More, what the heck are you talking about? Furthermore, what the heck am I talking about?
